bibl.title: Despatch from Ezekiel E. Smith to George L. Rives, March 11, 1889
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

correspAction.roleName: U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General

div1.p: Consulate General, U. S. A. Monrovia, Liberia, March 11, 1889
Mr. Ezekiel E. Smith To the Deartment of State.
Acknowledgment of the receipt of despatch no 4 of January 10th 1889. Explanation of despatch No 1 of November 6th 1888.
Consulate General, U. S. A. Monrovia, Liberia, March 11, 1889
Honorable G. L. Rives Assistant Secretary of State, Wasington, D. C.
Sir: I have the honor respectfully to acknolwedge the receipt of your No 4 despatch under dat of January 10th 89.

In explanation of my (incorrectly numbered 1) despatch of November 6th, transmitting a reply to the Departent circular of September 20th last, concerning the rates of duty levied on American goods; I wish to state that, prior to the reception of the circular above mentioned, I had received from the Department no document or communication over the signature of Hon, A. A. Adee; and as the despatches from one hitherto, had been addressed only to the Secretary and Assistant Secretary, I was not quite sure that a reply to
to a document, from Hon. A. A. Adee, should be numbered among them addressed to the Assistant secretary.
I am, sir, your obedient servant,
E. E. Smith U.S. Consul Gen'l
To Hon. G. L. Rives Assistant Secretary, Washington, D. C.
